questions.text: Both Vitamin K and C are involved in:
questions.solution:

Expl:Vitamin k – Carboxylation of Glutamic acid to form active form of clotting factor  II,IV,IX,X

Vitamin C- Hydroxylation of Proline

Nucleoside is Nitrogenous Base combined to Sugar.

questions.text: All of the following are substrates for gluconeogenesis except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

EXPL:Oleic acid is gives Acetyl Coa on complete Oxidation that does not form Glucose

questions.text: Increase in pyruvate and lactate is seen in which of the following deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

EXPL:

Many alcoholics are thiamin deficient (both because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamin absorption), and may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis

questions.text: Collagen is rich in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

EXPL: COLLAGEN IS repeating structure, represented as (Gly-X-Y)n, is an absolute requirement for the formation of the triple helix. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine occur principally in collagen.

questions.text: Amino acids excreted in the urine in cystinuria:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

EXPL:cystinlysinuria-due to defective renal absorption of cysteine and other basic amino acids, renal stones are also formed during this disease.

questions.text: DNA double helix is bound by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

EXPL:

Hydrogen bond bind the two strands of DNA where A=T while G≡C

choices.text: Accumulation of Long Chain Fatty Acids

questions.text: All are true for Zellweger Syndrome Except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

EXPL:In Zellweger syndrome their occurs Accumulation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acids due to defective genes encoding proteins called peroxins required for peroxisome formation.

questions.text: Examples of monounsaturated fatty acids are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Palmitoliec acid-16c having 1 double bond at 9 th position  from -COOH group oliec acid-18c having 1 double bond at 9 th position from -COOH group

questions.text: The Endogenous vitamin is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Niacin is not strictly a vitamin. Niacin deficiency causes pellagra. It is not strictly a vitamin since it can be synthesized in the body from the essential amino acid tryptophan

choices.text: Increased mobilization of glycogen from liver

questions.text: All are the true regarding glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

EXPL: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency  is seen in Von Gierkes disease is characterized by Fasting Hypoglycemia,  Hyperuricemia ,Lactic acidosis, Ketosis.

questions.text: A relatively free component of the electron transport respiratory chain is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

EXPL:Complex I transfers electron to NADH to coenzyme Q (Q) (also called ubiquinone),Q-cytochrome c oxidoreductase (Complex III), which passes the electrons on to cytochrome c; and cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV), which completes the chain, passing the electrons to O2 and causing it to be reduced to H2O. The four complexes are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane, but Q and cytochrome c are mobile.

questions.text: Which of the following is rich source of cholesterol:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

EXPL: Cholesterol occurs in foods of animal origin such as egg yolk, meat, liver, and brain.

questions.text: Non-essential amino acids are not:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

EXPL:

Essential Amino acids are required in diet.

questions.text: Glycogen storage disease include all the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

EXPL: Glycogen storage diseases are a group of inherited disorders characterized by deficient mobilization of glycogen or deposition of abnormal forms of glycogen, leading to liver damage and muscle weakness; some glycogen storage diseases result in early death.

•	Von Gierke disease 

•	Pompe disease 

•	Forbe or Cori disease 

•	Andersen disease 

•	McArdle syndrome 

•	Hers disease

questions.text: Gluconeogenesis mainly occurs in which of the following organs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

EXPL: Liver and kidney are the major gluconeogenic tissues; the kidney may contribute up to 40% of total glucose synthesis in the fasting state and more in starvation

questions.text: LDL lipoprotein is associated with :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Apoprotein B100

•	Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is one of the five major groups of lipoproteins, which in order of size, largest to smallest, are chylomicrons, VLDL, IDL, LDL, and HDL, that enable transport of multiple different fat molecules, including cholesterol, within the water around cells and within the water-based bloodstream

•	Each native LDL particle contains a single apolipoprotein B-100 molecule (Apo B-100, a protein that has 4536 amino acid residues and a mass of 514 kDa), which circulates the fatty acids, keeping them soluble in the aqueous environment. In addition, LDL has a highly hydrophobic core consisting of polyunsaturated fatty acid known as linoleate and about 1500 esterified cholesterol molecules.

questions.text: After a 72-hour fast the substance likely to the involved in the formation of energy would be :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acetoacetate

•	The ketone bodies, acetoacetate and 13-hydroxy butyrate are acids. 

•	In starvation, the dietary supply of glucose is decreased. The increased rate of lipolysis is to provide alternate source of fuel. 

•	The excess acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies. 

•	The high glucagon – insulin ratio prevailing under conditions of starvation favours ketogenesis. 

•	The brain derives 75% of energy from ketone bodies under conditions of fasting. 

•	Hyper-emesis in early pregnancy and prolonged labor are other causes for ketosis in clinical practice.

questions.text: Which among the following is a feature of noncompetitive inhibition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decreased Vmax

•    A noncompetitive inhibitor has no effect on Km. but decrease Vmax

•    Vmax : Maximum velocity  

•    Km : The substrate concentration at which the enzyme attains half of the Vmax

questions.text: A young lady presented with tingling sensation in legs and hands. On examination she had fissure tongue and lesions on the angle of mouth. On investigation, she had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Diagnosis is deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B2

questions.text: End product of Purine metabolism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Uric acid 

Ref: Biochemistry 3rd edition by SC  Rastogi page 366. 

Sol:

•	In human and higher primates, uric acid is the final oxidation (breakdown) product purine metabolism and is excreted in urine.

•	Allantion is a natural end product of purine metabolism in most mammals other than humans.

choices.text: Interferes with energy production from amino acids
Is cofactor for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency results in decrease energy production, because TPP:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Is cofactor for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:

•	Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is a derivative of thiamine (vitamin B1). 

•	Beriberi affects especially the brain, because TPP is required for carbohydrate metabolism, and the brain depends on glucose metabolism for energy.

•	Nutritional deficiency of thiamine leads to the disease beriberi.

•	Pyruvate carboxylase complex-Energy Metabolism

questions.text: Vitamin toxicity causing teratogenicity is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A         

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:  

•	Vitamin A has been found to have teratogenic role.

•	Retinoids, the synthetic derivates of vitamin A, have a key role on cellular differentiation and developmental tissue specificity. 

•	Their effects are mediated by nuclear receptors which transactivate homeobox genes.

•	They are teratogenic to animals and they all induce similar malformations dependent on the dose and the duration of exposure

questions.text: How is vitamin d synthesised :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Skin – Liver – Kidney

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:  

•	Produced in skin, cholecalciferol goes to liver where it is hydroxylated to produce 25 hydroxy-cholecalciferol which then enters the PCT  where is converted to 1,25 hydroxy cholecalciferol

•	1,25 hydroxy cholecalciferol is the most active form of vitamin D

questions.text: In humans, ascorbic acid can not be synthesized because of-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Deficiency of L-gulonolactone oxidase

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:  

•	In man, other primates and guinea pigs, ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized due to absence of L-gluconolactone oxidase, an enzyme used in lower animals to synthesize ascorbic acid as a byproduct of uronic acid pathway (Glucuronic acid cycle).

questions.text: Choose major lipid of inner mitochondrial membrane of heart from following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cardiolipin

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:  

Phosphatidic acid serves as a precursor of Phosphatidylglycerol, which subsequently produces Cardiolipin.
Cardiolipin is found only in mitochondria and is required for the mitochondrial function.

Decreased Cardiolipin levels or Alterations in its structure or metabolism lead to the following:

•	Pathological conditions such as Barth syndrome (cardiac skeletal myopathy), Heart Failure, Hypothyroidism

•	Mitochondrial Dysfunction in Aging

questions.text: The amino acid which serve as a carrier of ammonia from skeletal muscle to the liver is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alanine

Pyruvate is major keto acid which accepts amino group from various amino acids during transamination process. Pyruvate gets converted to alanine due to this transamination process. So major carrier of amino group to the liver from muscle is Alanine.

questions.text: Which of the accompanying is the main result of glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glucose-1-phosphate

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•	The reaction catalyzed by phosphoglucomutase is reversible, so that glucose-6-phosphate can be formed from glucose 1-phosphate.

•	In liver, but not muscle, glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate, yielding glucose that is exported, leading to an increase in the blood glucose concentration.

•	Glucose-6-phosphatase is in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, and genetic defects of the glucose-6-phosphate transporter can cause a variant of type I glycogen storage disease. 

•	Glucose 6 phosphate is the end product of glycogenolysis

questions.text: Enzymes mediating transfer of one molecule to another are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transferases mediate the transfer of once molecule to another. For e.g: methyltransferase.

questions.text: In which of the following reactions is magnesium required:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sodium potassium ATPase is a metallo enzyme that uses magnesium. Dismutase requires copper.

questions.text: In oxidative phosphorylation, the ATP production and respiratory chain are linked by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The removal of hydrogen ions from complex 4 contributes to the ion gradient used in the process of chemiosmosis. Chemiosmosis is the movement of ions across, down their electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: Thiamine level is best monitored by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Serum thiamine testing has poor sensitivity and specificity than transketolase levels.

Transketolase is an enzyme that requires thiamine as a cofactor and is highly useful in monitoring thiamine levels. Retic count is used for monitoring iron deficiency anaemia.

choices.text: Increased DNA synthesis in bone marrow

questions.text: Vitamin B12 and folic acid supplementation in megaloblastic Anemia leads to the improvement of Anemia due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B12 and folic acid are required for DNA synthesis. Deficiency of vitamin B12 and folic acid impairs DNA synthesis and hence cell division, thus, resulting in large immature cells k/a megaloblasts.

questions.text: Phenylalanine is the precursor of all the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Melatonin is synthesised from serotonin.

questions.text: In a well fed state, acetyl CoA obtained from diet is least used in the synthesis of:

Correct Answer (C)

Acetoacetate is ketone body which is synthesised during starvation.

choices.text: Cut at palindromes /specific sites on DNA

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease ,false is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Present in human

Restriction endonuclease acts on specific palindromic regions on DNA. It may produce 3’ or 5’ overhang depending on sequence it acts.

This enzyme is found in bacteria and plants but not in human being

questions.text: Vitamins required for converting Malonyl CoA to Succinyl CoA is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B12(adenosyl cobalamin)

Conversion of methyl malonyl Co A to Succinyl Co A needs methyl malonyl Co A mutase enzyme which needs adenosyl-cobalamin as a cofactor.
